attributes.title: Allegheny Technologies' Q3 2015 Earnings: So Poor, I'm Changing My View
summary: ATI reported a significant yoy and qoq decline in sales and earnings in 3Q15.
Key end-markets, including oil & gas, electrical energy, and automotive experienced sales declines in YTD 2015.

ATI appears to be losing market share, as evidenced by declining sales to the automotive market despite strong automobile unit sales, and the High Performance segment's margin "performance" has deteriorated.
With commentary from management that conditions will not improve until 2016 (which we've heard before), I've lost confidence in the management of this company.
At best, Allegheny Technologies Incorporated is now dead money through April 2016, when the company reports 1Q16 earnings; I'm moving to Neutral.

attributes.content:
In my first article on Allegheny Technologies Incorporated (NYSE: NYSE:ATI), when the stock was trading at $21, I argued that "ATI is now appropriately priced for a small, speculative entry long position for speculative (non-value oriented) investors willing to take substantial risk and average down." I believed that ATI's long-term agreements with aerospace aircraft/engine OEMs would allow the High Performance segment to maintain positive margins and some top line growth in an otherwise sales/margin-contracting environment. I argued that an abatement of nickel pricing, oil & gas, union labor, and operational execution headwinds could lead the stock higher, with the High Performance segment's aerospace exposure providing ballast in a turbulent steel and specialty metal environment.

I followed that article up with a second article arguing that ATI should consider splitting into two companies, similar to Alcoa's (AA) action taken a month ago. I elaborated on my belief that Allegheny Technologies Incorporated's High Performance segment alone could be worth more than the entire company was valued at the time (slightly higher than it is today). I based my EBITDA valuation on ATI's High Performance segment's 1H15 EBITDA annualized, which implied my view that High Performance sales and EBITDA margins were sustainable through the remainder of the year, mostly due to strong aerospace & defense exposure.

I was wrong; ATI's 3Q15 report showed that things can, and did, get much worse

But I was wrong. ATI's 3Q15 report included sharp declines in High Performance revenues and margins; even aerospace & defense volumes declined qoq. But it was the damning realization that ATI appears to be losing market share in most non-aerospace & defense markets that put the "nail in the (proverbial) coffin," in my view. Asset utilization appears to be declining to a point that ATI can no longer remain profitable, even in its High Performance segment.
